page.title: 09SOCIAL LIFE IN THIS AREA
page.content: village life changed. Horse-drawn vehicles were replaced by motorised transport. This, coupled with the purchase of family cars, increased the dangers from traffic and effectively banished children's traditional games from the streets. Shortage of work, following the exhaustion of local coal seams, resulted in the removal of families. The influx of strangers along with the now-transient population marked the end of static community life.
